thread.title: The Wall Street Journal: In court, AT&T CEO describes Time Warner acquisition as a ‘vision deal’

title: The Wall Street Journal: In court, AT&T CEO describes Time Warner acquisition as a ‘vision deal’
text:
Published: Apr 19, 2018 4:46 p.m. ET Share 
Randall Stephenson takes the stand in antitrust trial Reuters AT&T CEO Randall Stephenson, right, arrives at U.S. District Court in Washington on Thursday 
By Brent Kendall Drew FitzGerald 
WASHINGTON — AT&T Inc. Chief Executive Randall Stephenson began his eagerly awaited testimony in court Thursday in defense of his company’s proposed Time Warner Inc. acquisition, calling it a “vision deal” that was crucial for AT&T to compete in a rapidly shifting digital-media landscape. 
Time Warner “met all the needs we were looking for,” Stephenson told U.S. District Judge Richard Leon, who is deciding whether to allow the $85 billion transaction. 
The AT&T chief took the witness stand shortly after noon in a dark suit and blue tie, explaining his long history with the company and how he came to believe that AT&T T, -1.11% , with its wireless and satellite assets, needed to own a media company like Time Warner TWX, -0.54% , which owns the Turner networks, HBO and Warner Bros. studios. 
Stephenson said AT&T was focused on growing so it could compete for advertising dollars with technology giants like Amazon.com Inc. AMZN, +1.90% , Facebook Inc. FB, +1.05% and Google owner Alphabet Inc. GOOGL, +1.31% GOOG, +1.46% , rather than the traditional TV providers that vie for its customers today.
